title: How to Make a Period Kit

steps.title: Get a small bag or purse.
steps.content: Get a small bag or purse. [1] X Research source You need something to serve as your kit! But make sure it is big enough to hold pads and, if you use them, tampons. It would be handy if it had compartments! You might not want a bag that is too big if you plan on carrying it around with you.

steps.title: Get some menstrual products.
steps.content: Get some menstrual products. Usually, your first period is very light and just spotting, so pantyliners are perfect. For a heavier flow, you'll want pads or tampons. Alternatives are menstrual/soft cups , period underwear or reusable, cloth pads. You'll need about three liners and three pads or tampons to last you through a work or school day. Be sure to change your pad every 4-6 hours and your tampon every 6-8 hours. [2] X Research source Try out different levels of absorbency for products to find out what works for you. [3] X Expert Source Rebecca Levy-Gantt, MPT, DO Board Certified Obstetrician & Gynecologist Expert Interview. 3 April 2020. It is likely you will need different absorbencies for different times of your period. If you plan on using period underwear or reusable pads, take along an extra bag to keep used ones in.

steps.title: Add pain medications.
steps.content: Add pain medications. There's a high possibility you'll get period cramps, which aren't pleasant. Ibuprofen works well to reduce the pain and it may reduce flow for some people. [4] X Expert Source Rebecca Levy-Gantt, MPT, DO Board Certified Obstetrician & Gynecologist Expert Interview. 3 April 2020. Make sure that you don't exceed the daily limit listed on the label. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Usually you can take one or two 200mg tablets at a time up to three or four times daily. [6] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Add a small calendar and pen.
steps.content: Add a small calendar and pen. If you're unsure of when exactly your period is, write down the date every month until you find your pattern. [7] X Research source Keeping a diary for this purpose is also very useful. You can also take note of other symptoms you experience throughout the month to get a better idea of what to expect.

steps.title: Include extra underwear.
steps.content: Include extra underwear. [8] X Research source Extra underwear can be helpful, especially if you stain your current pair of undies. In this case, you'll want a Ziploc bag to hold your stained panties. You may find that wearing period underwear before and during your period can help prevent stains. You can wear them with or without another period product.

steps.title: Add in an extra pair of bottoms as well if you have space.
steps.content: Add in an extra pair of bottoms as well if you have space. This is in case your period is exceptionally heavy and your product leaks through to your clothes. It can be uncomfortable to be wearing blood soaked clothes. If this is a regular problem, consider doubling up on period products, changing your product to something that doesn't leak, or taking birth control for lighter periods. Be aware of the hormonal changes that occur with the consumption of birth control pills. Only use it if you know the pros and cons. [9] X Research source Talk to your doctor if you experience a lot of leakage and excessively heavy flow! [10] X Expert Source Rebecca Levy-Gantt, MPT, DO Board Certified Obstetrician & Gynecologist Expert Interview. 3 April 2020. This could be the sign of an underlying condition, such as endometriosis or fibroids.

steps.title: Get some hand sanitizer.
steps.content: Get some hand sanitizer. It always helps when the bathroom's out of soap!

steps.title: Include some flushable wipes.
steps.content: Include some flushable wipes. Make sure that they are biodegradable and not scented. Scented products can cause vaginal irritation.

steps.title: Add in a small plastic bag to hold soiled underwear and/or pants.
steps.content: Add in a small plastic bag to hold soiled underwear and/or pants. A plastic bag can also be useful if there is not a place to dispose of a used tampon or pad (on a hike, at the beach, etc.)

steps.title: Put in some spare change, in case you forget to refill your kit and need to get some from a machine.
steps.content: Put in some spare change, in case you forget to refill your kit and need to get some from a machine.

steps.title: Put in some chocolate (optional), especially dark chocolate - make sure it's in a Ziploc bag as well.
steps.content: Put in some chocolate (optional), especially dark chocolate - make sure it's in a Ziploc bag as well. The chemicals in chocolate can help with your cramps and satisfy that craving you're probably having. [11] X Research source
